760a5957-38d9-4bee-9d82-8379d121ffd6.description: Earners of the Online Course Design (Fundamentals) badge will have been an active participant in the two-week Online Teaching Boot Camp facilitated by Quinnipiac University’s Academic Technology Department and School of Education Instructional Design Faculty. Earners demonstrated a basic knowledge of the guiding principles of teaching in an online space. Earners will be able to apply the ideas, strategies and tools learned to create their own effective online courses.
760a5957-38d9-4bee-9d82-8379d121ffd6.name: Online Course Design (Fundamentals)

badge_template_activities.title: Be a Quinnipiac University employee

Earners of the badge successfully completed the Quinnipiac University Online Teaching Boot Camp and were active participants within the course.  Active participation included  completing readings, viewing lectures, contributing to discussion boards and  using key technological learning resources.  The boot camp consisted of the following modules:  Opening the Door | Structuring & Centering | Teaching Strategies | Building Community.

Earners of the badge completed the following activities:  • Posted an initial response to the discussion prompt in each module • Replied to at least one of their peers in each discussion • Submitted the "Planning Your Course" learning activity at the end of Module 2 • Submitted the "Communications Plan Journal" at the end of Module 4.

Participants successfully mastered the learning objectives for Module 1 (Opening the Door)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Consider preconceived ideas about online learning  | Convey online presence through tone and language | Establish place, culture and rhythm in an online course.

Participants successfully mastered the learning objectives for Module 2 (Structuring & Centering)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Emphasize the importance of creating a "central location" for content and communications  |Describe the overall structure of an asynchronous course in Blackboard.

Participants successfully mastered the learning objectives for Module 3 (Teaching Strategies)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Explore strategies for engaging learners and foster learning in online spaces | List the affordances of available tools in the online space.

Participants successfully mastered the learning objectives for Module 4 (Building Community)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Recognize the role of community within an online course  | Establish their own guidelines for communicating with students | Develop a communications plan for their online course

a41ee89e-25f5-448e-ab99-471bfcb7f462.description: The Working Through Others Leadership Development Program equips and empowers managers to effectively lead teams through the ever-changing healthcare landscape. Through this 12-week modular program leaders apply strategies and tools to solve problems, increases organizational awareness, build networks, and cultivate self-knowledge.
a41ee89e-25f5-448e-ab99-471bfcb7f462.name: Leadership Development Program: Working Through Others

badge_template_activities.title: Participants apply a collection of professional competencies in simulated and professional environments. Through a 12-week modular employer-sponsored program, leaders develop knowledge, skills, and abilities and demonstrate their learning by applying strategies and tools to address workplace challenges. Areas of focus include building and retaining high performing teams and leading change.

skills.name: Coaching, Mentoring, and Being a Talent Multiplier

401f8236-e61b-42c6-8d62-a37a7f542fad.description: Earners of the Online Course Design Boot Camp (Instructor) badge demonstrated an expert level of the knowledge, skills and abilities required to design and deliver an online learning course. Instructors facilitated faculty development related to the guiding principles of teaching in the online space, as well as specific features and strategies that can help support online learning. Instructors guided boot camp participants in the practical application of the ideas, strategies, and tools.
401f8236-e61b-42c6-8d62-a37a7f542fad.name: Online Course Design Boot Camp (Instructor)

badge_template_activities.title: Instructor for the Quinnipiac University Online Teaching Boot Camp. The boot camp sought to answer the question " What does it take to design an online learning experience that engages students and fosters their construction of new understandings – and how can we pivot quickly to an online format?"  The course consisted of the following modules:  Opening the Door | Structuring & Centering | Teaching Strategies | Building Community and was conducted asynchronously over the course of two weeks.
Participated in the curricular design and creation of the QU Online Teaching Boot Camp.

Designed and delivered learning experiences so that active  participants could successfully masteri the learning objectives for Module 1 (Opening the Door)  Consider preconceived ideas about online learning  | Convey online presence through tone and language | Establish place, culture and rhythm in an online course.

Designed and delivered learning experiences so that active  participants could successfully master the learning objectives for Module 2 (Structuring & Centering)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Emphasize the importance of creating a "central location" for content and communications  |Describe the overall structure of an asynchronous course in Blackboard.

Designed and delivered learning experiences so that active  participants could successfully master the learning objectives for Module 3 (Teaching Strategies)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Explore strategies for engaging learners and foster learning in online spaces | List the affordances of available tools in the online space.

Designed and delivered learning experiences so that active  participants could successfully master the learning objectives for Module 4 (Building Community)  and have a fundamental understanding of how to:  Recognize the role of community within an online course  | Establish their own guidelines for communicating with students | Develop a communications plan for their online course

006c0e31-b929-46ac-862f-cdff6d7f1139.description: Students who meet the requirements are eligible to receive this badge from the Committee for Community and Civic Engagement that reflects the commitment they have made to designated courses and co-curricular community and civic engagement activities.
006c0e31-b929-46ac-862f-cdff6d7f1139.name: Community and Civic Engagement

badge_template_activities.title: Students must successfully complete (grade of C or better) two designated service learning courses; complete two sustained community or civic engagement experiences with a completed reflection; or a combination of a service learning course with a sustained community or civic engagement experiences with a completed reflection. Learning activities will be assessed by some members of the Community and Civic Engagement committee.

Eligible engagement opportunities include:  1. Service learning courses;  or other courses linked with community or civic engagement application; 2. Alternative spring break trips, Albert Schweitzer Institute trips, or Global Solidarity trips;  3. Global Public Health student placement; 4. Sustained service in the community or on campus (a semester or more).  *paid positions will not be accepted

Learning activities will be assessed by some members of the Community and Civic Engagement committee using a rubric At the time of application, the applicant shall submit an essay no longer than 1000 words which references the two experiences while responding to the following prompts:  1. How has community or civic engagement helped to shape your concept of who you are in relation to community?  2. How has your community or civic engagement impacted your community?

5af92742-6dd3-4e3b-b45a-61f9b1bd00f9.description: Each student who completes the badging program to earn graduation distinction in interprofessional healthcare education will be able to: a. list each of the core competencies of interprofessional healthcare (IPEC, 2018); b. describe each core competency; c. identify each competency in patient simulations and standardized patient cases; d. apply each competency when working in an interprofessional team of students when given a patient; and e. analyze a patient or healthcare scenario.
5af92742-6dd3-4e3b-b45a-61f9b1bd00f9.name: Interprofessional Healthcare Education

alignments.name: Shared Values and Ethics
alignments.description: Interprofessional Core Competencies for Collaborative Practice (IPEC, 2016) Work with individuals of other professions to maintain a climate of mutual respect and shared values (VE Values and Ethics).

alignments.name: Understanding Diverse Roles and Responsibilities
alignments.description: Interprofessional Core Competencies for Collaborative Practice (IPEC, 2016) Use the knowledge of one’s own role and those of other professions to appropriately assess and address the health care needs of patients and to promote and advance the health of populations. (Roles/Responsibilities)

alignments.name: Interprofessional Communication
alignments.description: Interprofessional Core Competencies for Collaborative Practice (IPEC, 2016) Communicate with patients, families, communities, and professionals in health and other fields in a responsive and responsible manner that supports a team approach to the promotion and maintenance of health and the prevention and treatment of disease. (Inter. Com.)

alignments.name: Teams and Teamwork
alignments.description: Interprofessional Core Competencies (IPEC, 2016) Apply relationship-building values and the principles of team dynamics to perform effectively in different team roles to plan, deliver, and evaluate patient/population centered care and population health programs and policies that are safe, timely, efficient, effective, and equitable.

badge_template_activities.title: Basic knowledge and skills in interprofessional healthcare ( 4 online learning modules and/or formal case studies). These 20 hours will allow the student to meet the learning objectives as listed above: a. list each of the core competencies of interprofessional healthcare (IPEC, 2018); b. describe each core competency; c. identify each competency in patient simulations and standardized patient cases. Assessment: reflection essays with faculty feedback.

Basic knowledge and skills in interprofessional healthcare ( 4 online learning modules and/or formal case studies). These 20 hours will allow the student to meet the learning objectives as listed above: a. list each of the core competencies of interprofessional healthcare (IPEC, 2018); b. describe each core competency; c. identify each competency in patient simulations and standardized patient cases.

Experiential learning activities in interprofessional healthcare (20 hours). The experiential learning is a series of 3-4 hour seminars of interaction with interprofessional teams of students. These 20 hours will allow the student to meet the learning objectives as listed above: d. apply each competency when working in an interprofessional team of students when given a patient.  Learning objectives a, b and c will be reinforced.

Project based learning of 20 hours of interprofessional healthcare community based service, leadership activities in interprofessional healthcare, or facilitation of interprofessional seminars. These hours  meet the objectives as listed above: e. analyze a patient or healthcare scenario to examine evidence, make inferences, use evidence to propose solutions to the healthcare scenario utilizing skills on interprofessional care.

4ffe5ca6-88c3-4bbb-9c65-31a3abcbc98a.description: Badge earners complete two courses, earn a Google Data Analytics Certification, and demonstrate application of a collection of competencies resulting in a portfolio of their work. Earners apply working knowledge of essential data analysis platforms including when and how to use them in the data lifecycle, translate a business question into a data analysis exercise, distill findings from data into actionable takeaways, and demonstrate the ability to work with data responsibly.
4ffe5ca6-88c3-4bbb-9c65-31a3abcbc98a.name: Applied Google Data Analytics

badge_template_activities.title: Completion of two courses, which embed the Google Data Analytics Certification in addition to other course requirements such as discussions, peer review, and more.
Completion of professional projects demonstrating knowledge, skills, and abilities.
Creating of a portfolio reflecting the professional projects they completed through the two courses.

Submission of the portfolio to a professional in the field or career coach and reflection paper identifying how the results of the portfolio review will be integrated to improve use of the professional portfolio.
Completion of the Google Data Analytics Certification through Coursera embedded in QU courses.

ccf06df3-65bb-423e-8c73-14d1a5e212a7.description: This micro-credential is awarded to Student Workers who demonstrate excellence in applied research skills relevant to the research project or study (including competency in digital technology), communication related to the academic discipline or field of study, creative problem solving, and professionalism (including teamwork, if relevant). Only student workers, paid or volunteer, who are engaged in a research project or study with a faculty or staff member are eligible to apply for the badge.
ccf06df3-65bb-423e-8c73-14d1a5e212a7.name: Applied Research Level III

alignments.name: Academic Habits of Mind (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Self-regulation, competency to work autonomously, ability to make sound decisions about the way time is used and to prioritize work; study skills, strong work ethic, curiosity to explore the world intellectually, and the process of inquiry that is common to all academic disciplines.

alignments.name: Competency in Handling Cognitive Complexity (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Identify problems in a range of contexts and develop effective solutions; Examine complex issues logically from a range of perspectives; Analyze complex situations where clear and unambiguous solutions may not be available; Contextualize complex concepts ; Rethink and unlearn previous conviction as part of becoming an independent thinker.

alignments.name: Competency in Inquiry (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Find, critically evaluate, and analyze information from diverse sources efficiently and logically; Analyze written and visual texts; Consider multiple possible explanations and interrogate alternative explanations with critical evidence; Synthesize, integrate, and adapt across general and specialized contexts, old and new.

alignments.name: Competency in Analysis and Data Skills (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Make sense of patterns and anomalies in evidence and data; Distinguish between core and peripheral information; Recognize, use, and demonstrate appreciation for the multiplicity of methods; Evaluate and construct arguments based on logic and evidence; Apply acquired knowledge and skills to new contexts and problems independently.

badge_template_activities.title: Students contribute to an original research project or study that is designed to result in the faculty or staff member’s scholarly activity, including creation of original content, presentations, publications, and other creative scholarship. The nature of the contribution will depend upon the academic discipline of the supervising faculty or staff member as well as the modes of inquiry of the relevant field of study.

Students prepare an ePortfolio that describes contributions and highlights skills and knowledge gained. The ePortfolio must include a letter from the supervising faculty or staff member which describes the ways in which the student has earned the Level III badge. Assessment of completion of micro-credential requirements is completed by a jury evaluation or comparable mechanism. Students who contribute to a research project sponsored by a faculty or staff member may apply for the Level III badge.
The micro-credential is not associated with Academic Credit.

9bc2578e-64be-4b9e-a75b-9da0e65b0d0b.description: This micro-credential is awarded to Student Workers who demonstrate excellence in applied research skills relevant to the research project or study, communication related to the academic discipline or field of study, creative problem solving, and professionalism (including teamwork, if relevant). Only student workers, paid or volunteer, who co-present at a professional conference or co-author scholarly work are eligible for a Level IV badge.
9bc2578e-64be-4b9e-a75b-9da0e65b0d0b.name: Applied Research Level IV

alignments.name: Academic Habits of Mind (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Self-regulation, competency to work autonomously, ability to make sound decisions about the way time is used and to prioritize work; study skills, strong work ethic, curiosity to explore the world intellectually, and the process of inquiry that is common to all academic disciplines.

alignments.name: Competency in Handling Cognitive Complexity (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Identify problems in a range of contexts and develop effective solutions; Examine complex issues logically from a range of perspectives; Analyze complex situations where clear and unambiguous solutions may not be available; Contextualize complex concepts ; Rethink and unlearn previous conviction as part of becoming an independent thinker.

alignments.name: Competency in Inquiry (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Find, critically evaluate, and analyze information from diverse sources efficiently and logically; Analyze written and visual texts; Consider multiple possible explanations and interrogate alternative explanations with critical evidence; Synthesize, integrate, and adapt across general and specialized contexts, old and new.

alignments.name: Competency in Analysis and Data Skills (QU Essential Learning Outcome - Inquiry & Analysis)
alignments.description: Make sense of patterns and anomalies in evidence and data; Distinguish between core and peripheral information; Recognize, use, and demonstrate appreciation for the multiplicity of methods; Evaluate and construct arguments based on logic and evidence; Apply acquired knowledge and skills to new contexts and problems independently.

badge_template_activities.title: Students contribute to an original research project or study that is designed to result in the faculty or staff member’s scholarly activity, including creation of original content, presentations, publications, and other creative scholarship. The nature of the contribution will depend upon the academic discipline of the supervising faculty or staff member as well as the modes of inquiry of the relevant field of study.

Students prepare an ePortfolio that describes contributions and highlights skills and knowledge gained. The ePortfolio must include a letter from the supervising faculty or staff member which describes the ways in which the student has earned the Level IV badge. Assessment of completion of micro-credential requirements is completed by a jury evaluation or comparable mechanism. Students who contribute to a research project sponsored by a faculty or staff member may apply for the Level III badge.
The micro-credential is not associated with Academic Credit.

584da6aa-44ae-4bfb-897f-40773da4605c.description: The QU Engineering Writing Badge (QUEWB) signifies an engineering student with exceptional skills in writing within a range of tasks, such as lab reports, memos, feasibility plans, and analyses. To earn the EWB, students will meet a set of particular benchmarks set by professionals as well as faculty. Benchmarks will include: language conventions, logical development, problem-solving, and synthesis of appropriate evidence.
584da6aa-44ae-4bfb-897f-40773da4605c.name: Engineering Writer

badge_template_activities.title: Students submit a writing sample of their choice from ENR 110 to an eportfolio. Students respond to the reflection prompt: Articulate the professional identity you hope to present upon graduation; Explain why you chose the particular writing sample and how it demonstrates your professional identity. The sample and reflection are evaluated on a rubric designed by faculty in Engineering, English, as well as professional engineering writers. Students will receive feedback from the rubric evaluators

After receiving feedback, students submit a new writing sample from either an additional ENR course or a professional experience to an eportfolio. Students also complete another reflection, using the same prompt as above. The sample and reflection are again evaluated on the same rubric. Students who demonstrate growth towards their professional identity will be awarded the QUEWB.

fe9abf33-a25c-4d26-9dea-781de112009b.description: Earners of this badge will be proficient in establishing, implementing and maturing an Enterprise Cybersecurity Risk Management (ECRM) program. Earners will review case studies of healthcare organizations and determine how they did or did not secure their health information. Earners will know how to organize for effective security defense including: governance, people, process, technology and engagement. Earners have hands-on experience using risk management tools.
fe9abf33-a25c-4d26-9dea-781de112009b.name: Enterprise Cybersecurity Risk Management in Healthcare

alignments.name: HIPAA Regulations
alignments.description: Primary federal law for healthcare privacy, security and breach notification

alignments.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
alignments.description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Cybersecurity Framework is voluntary guidance, based on existing standards, guidelines, and practices for organizations to better manage and reduce cybersecurity risk.

badge_template_activities.title: Developing an Enterprise Cybersecurity Risk Management (ECRM) plan for a model healthcare organization
Participating in discussions throughout the program
Completing exams during the program

8890bc1d-7507-4027-8859-e64962d349e0.description: This micro-credential is awarded to students demonstrating foundational skills in client-side and server-side programming of web development, as well as web analytics. Through projects in a series of courses, students learn and apply design principles, responsive layouts, accessibility, performance optimization, version control systems, architectural patterns, database integration, authentication, authorization, security, measurement planning, data collection, audience characteristics, and more.
8890bc1d-7507-4027-8859-e64962d349e0.name: Foundations of Web Development

badge_template_activities.title: Students will create websites using client-side and server-side programming.
Students will use web analytics to understand online user behavior.
Students completing the micro-credential will be prepared to complete the Google Analytics Individual Qualification exam.

7eba6107-588a-4820-adb8-35343f8dda37.description: Badge earners demonstrate competencies surrounding contemporary issues of gender, sexuality, and women’s studies in local and global contexts. Learners gain nuanced, interdisciplinary understandings of various concepts through several fields and are able to analyze current social and political issues about sex and gender through a contemporary lens to address inequity and oppression. Learners are able to identify social problems across institutions and apply new knowledge in a range of contexts.
7eba6107-588a-4820-adb8-35343f8dda37.name: Gender & Society

badge_template_activities.title: Learners complete a project (e.g., digital story, short film, poster presentation) where they identify a social/structural problem based on gender/sexual inequality, provide historical/background information about the problem, demonstrate how various disciplines both view and understand the problem, identify steps to resolve or lessen inequality, analyze why or how this process is or is not currently taking place, and discuss how this problem intersects with one’s own context or setting.
Learners must complete two courses from two different disciplines chosen from an identified list of courses related to gender, sexuality, and women's studies.

skills.name: Recognition of Social Stratification and Inequity

030f58d2-2d86-4bb0-bc90-6339c0cd9150.description: Earners of this badge are introduced to the HIPAA Privacy, Security and Breach Notification Regulations. With a focus on regulations and compliance earners will (1) Be able to list the principle requirements of the HIPAA Privacy Rule, Security Rule and Breach Notification Rule; (2) Be able to evaluate these rules within an organization using an automated tool, (3) Be able to assess the rules in their own healthcare organizations, and (4) will get hands-on experience with assessment tools.
030f58d2-2d86-4bb0-bc90-6339c0cd9150.name: Hands-On HIPAA Compliance Risk Management

alignments.name: HIPAA Regulations
alignments.description: Primary Federal law for healthcare privacy, security and breach notification

badge_template_activities.title: Presenting a HIPAA Compliance assessment of a model organization
Participating in class discussions throughout the program
Completing the exams within the program

eea3dd82-57d5-475a-b2a0-bdf3e4b48768.description: Earners of this badge will be knowledgeable of both theory and practice of enterprise cybersecurity risk management focused on healthcare organizations. Beyond compliance risks, earners will know the risks related to safeguarding the exploding quantities of healthcare data, systems and devices. Earners will have knowledge of best practices for risk analysis and the demands of the Office for Civil Rights. Earners will demonstrate proficiency in using a risk analysis tool.
eea3dd82-57d5-475a-b2a0-bdf3e4b48768.name: Hands-On HIPAA Security Risk Analysis and Risk Management

alignments.name: HIPAA Regulations
alignments.description: Primary federal law for healthcare privacy, security and breach notification

alignments.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
alignments.description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Cybersecurity Framework is voluntary guidance, based on existing standards, guidelines, and practices for organizations to better manage and reduce cybersecurity risk.

badge_template_activities.title: Presenting a Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) security risk analysis of a model organization
Participating in class discussions throughout the program
Completing the exams within the program

170418b2-b361-42fc-b3a2-9aa9cb708404.description: Students will apply knowledge of ethical standards to the protection of human subjects in research while applying selected elements of the research process with the guidance of an experienced research faculty mentor or engage in improvement science. Students will collaborate with nurses or other health care professionals in the process of disseminating (a) research evidence or (b) the application of scientific evidence as a poster/podium presentation, or publication.
170418b2-b361-42fc-b3a2-9aa9cb708404.name: Undergraduate Nursing Research Distinction

alignments.name: CITI RCR Training
alignments.description: CITI RCR training is described above. The CITI RCR training is valid for five years. Therefore, after graduation, the student may want this documentation available.

alignments.name: American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) Essentials of Nurses Baccalaureate Education
alignments.description: The SON is accredited by the AACN. The Essentials outline the necessary curriculum content and expected competencies of graduates. Essential III: Scholarship for Evidence Based Practice - professional nursing practice is grounded in the translation of current evidence into one’s practice.

alignments.name: American Holistic Nurses Credentialing Corporation (AHNCC)
alignments.description: The SON undergraduate program is Holistic Endorsed by the AHNCC. The current standards of practice of holistic nursing are based on five holistic core values. The first and fifth core values address are holistic ethics, theory, and research.

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI) on-line required competency for all faculty & students involved in research (4 hours). CITI: platform hosting the online training modules for Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR). RCR means following applicable laws, rules, and guidelines to ensure research is conducted honestly, accurately, and ethically. The CITI RCR Basic Course is offered through QU Center for Research & Scholarship. A Certificate of Completion is awarded.
Attend (in person/virtually) pre-approved scholarly activities related to the dissemination or application of nursing research (26 hours).

Participate in guided experiential learning activities related to nursing research and evidence-based practice. (40 hours). Conduct own research with faculty mentor guidance (ex. QU summer research). Collaborate on faculty's research/improvement science initiative (data collection, analysis, data displays, study appraisal, EB/QI team).

Present the study/scholarship experience involvement in writing an evidence-based practice (EBP) standard; involvement in an EBP improvement initiative), guided by faculty mentor. Presentation may be a poster or podium presentation at a conference, webinar, or other key event.
